Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Baek Soo Lee of Oregon State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Slope and historical land management effects on the nitrogen cycle in a Japanese forest watershed" during the summer of 2012 at Hokkaido University in Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan. The host scientist is Dr. Hideaki Shibata.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to better understand mechanisms of the nitrogen cycle in relation to slope and historical land use as well as to improve land management decision-making processes for enhancing water and soil quality. This research addresses several new aspects of the influence of slope and forest management history on nitrogen cycling in surface water and soil within a forest ecosystem using spatial and statistical analyses and is being conducted in the Nakagawa Experimental Forest in Hokkaido, the northernmost island of Japan.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This preliminary study addressed the influence of vegetation types and historical forest management practices on the nitrogen cycle in surface waters and soils within a selective-cut forest ecosystem at an Experimental Forest in Hokkaido, Japan using spatial and statistical analyses. This study and the continuation of this type of study could benefit human health by improving drinking water quality. There are large cities in the U.S. that put their efforts to watershed protection instead of filtration to provide safe drinking water. One way to protect such watersheds is to have a pristine environment by increasing forest areas rather than agriculture or urban land use. However it is known that old-growth forests do not store nitrogen compared to young forests, and therefore releases nitrogen to streams. Increase in nitrogen levels in waters can cause possible increase in hazardous algae blooms and health concerns such as a blue baby syndrome caused by nitrate.  However selective-cutting could be the way to avoid this issue.

This study is also significant in advancing the collaboration of Japan Long Term Ecological Research (JaLTER) and U.S. LTER. This study revealed the importance of understory-vegetation to the nitrogen cycle, which is often ignored due to the general focus on trees. 

This preliminary study found that nitrate production rate was the highest in soils of abundant understory vegetation, Sasa, in the control compared to the one in a selective-cut compartment treated over the last 40 years to maintain a total biomass. This observation could be due to the difference in Sasa’s habitat conditions in two compartments. Sasa in the control could not be found easily among trees as opposed to Sasa growing among trees in a selective-cut compartment. Thus, soils of Sasa in the control were collected from a location where no trees were nearby.

High nitrification rates were also found in old-growth forests by a previous study. Understory vegetation, Sasa, which was not influenced by trees and could survive after 40 years of the forest history in the control, may have grown under optimal conditions and been acting like old trees. Thus, the contribution of dominant understory vegetation to the nitrogen cycle should be investigated further.

This opportunity provided ample opportunities for a PI, who is a Ph.D. student, to learn new techniques in soil sampling and testing for N species in the laboratory. This project also provided an experience for the PI to learn how to communicate efficiently with Japanese scientists and students to maintain good working relationships for future collaboration. This project also helped improve the PI’s Japanese language skill that is beneficial to promote the collaboration work between Japan and the U.S. in the future.
